Award.AwardTitle: EarthCube RCN: Collaborative Research: Engaging the Greenland Ice Sheet Ocean (GRISO) Science Network
Award.AbstractNarration:
Greenland ice loss quadrupled over the last two decades and presently accounts for one quarter of global sea level rise. The ice loss is due to changes in surface mass balance and ice sheet dynamics associated with rising air and ocean temperatures. The associated increasing freshwater discharge is impacting the regional ocean, including its ecosystems, and has the potential to impact the large-scale North Atlantic circulation. Thus, Greenland's changes are having far-reaching consequences for global societies, yet the mechanisms responsible for these changes are not well understood. Dynamic ice loss, in particular, was likely triggered by changes at the margins of marine-terminating glaciers, through ice/ocean/atmosphere processes that are either absent or poorly represented in climate, ice sheet and ocean models. The interaction of the ocean, the glaciers and atmosphere at Greenland?s margins is a new research frontier. The complex processes involved include the coupling of multiple components of the Earth system, the challenges of obtaining and integrating diverse data from this region, and of modeling such a complex system. These challenges make this a problem that can only be addressed by bringing together multiple disciplines, including data management, collaboratively exploring diverse approaches and working across national borders. This project establishes a network to help scientists working in this area to share their data and work collaboratively.

The goal of this project is to substantially enhance multi-disciplinary activities and collaboration through the establishment of the GRISO (Greenland Ice Sheet Ocean) Science Network - an international, multidisciplinary, open network of scientists and cyberinfrastructure experts. Participants have a shared interested in advancing collective understanding of problems related to Greenland Ice Sheet change and its impact on regional and global climate. GRISO RCN activities will bring together scientists focused on all aspects of ice/ocean/atmosphere/climate data in Greenland and provide a framework for productive collaborative interaction. Specific objectives include two workshops, and a series of synthesis efforts. Additionally, a virtual data portal, leveraging existing infrastructure, will make interdisciplinary data submission and data availability easier and promote uniform and appropriate data management practices. The RCN builds on activities initiated by the former GRISO US CLIVAR Working Group and explicitly addresses priorities identified in a report from an international workshop held in 2013.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The world's two largest ice sheets (Greenland and Antarctica) are shrinking rapidly, through both increased melting and increased production of icebergs. This reduction in ice volume directly results in sea level rise. However, as scientists, we do not fully understand how the ice sheets are melting so rapidly, and what the implications of that extra ice loss (either melt or icebergs) will be on local areas.

Our project focused on the Greenland Ice Sheet in particular, to create a network of scientists: the Greenland Ice Sheet Ocean (GRISO) network. We aimed to build the connections among disparate fields, such as oceanography, glaciology, hydrology, and meteorology, that are needed to make progress in unraveling the impacts of a rapidly changing ice sheet. We accomplished this by forming a grassroots community of scientists from around the world interested in how Greenland's ice interacts with its surrounding oceans. We held several successful workshops attended by a diverse group of scientists. One December 2017 workshop was convened at the Fall American Geophysical Union conference; a follow-on to that meeting is occurring this December 2018 and is specifically focused on the effects of the fresh meltwater from Greenland. The GRISO community we built through this project is robust and active: more information on its activities can be found at https://griso-network.org/. Loss of Greenland ice via ice-ocean interactions also influences sea level rise, an impact felt around the globe. To review and summarize these connections, GRISO also supported publication of a review paper, Rising Oceans Guaranteed: Arctic Land Ice Loss and Sea Level Rise (doi.org/10.1007/s40641-018-0107-0).

Another successful connection sparked by GRISO was the creation and subsequent publication of a new topography/bathymetry database for the entire Greenland Ice Sheet. These data are enormously difficult to get, but also extremely helpful to all scientists studying the ice sheet. These data are now free and publicly available to all, published in the journal Geophysical Research letters by Morlighem et al. in 2017 (doi.org/10.1002/2017GL074954).

Finally, although this project covered only a two-year period, we brought together an international team of scientists to develop a vision for a long-term monitoring program around the Greenland Ice Sheet that will serve society and scientists for decades to come. The resulting Greenland Ice Ocean Observing System (GrIOOS), described in a submitted manuscript to the upcoming OceanObs'19 conference (http://www.oceanobs19.net/), represents a step-change in our observational capacity around Greenland. GrIOOS will drastically improve our understanding of mechanisms that influence sea level rise, impacts of increased freshwater flux to the North Atlantic Ocean, and local and regional ecosystem effects from a changing ice sheet. A successful GrIOOS satisfies the needs of many distinct end-users, from the scientific community of global climate modelers to ecosystem and ice-ocean researchers to local communities and regional government entities around Greenland.
